She wears a pink and white skirt as she sits frightened on a wooden floor, holding a staff of pink and red flowers with leaves falling from it. Behind her is a wraith, their fanged mouth wide open, its two large skeletal hands reaching for her on both sides.

entries.name: Silvercut Roadway
entries: Namnet kommer från skimret av ändlösa fält av vindpinat, solbelyst gräs som följer vägen. {@book Silvercut Roadway|TDCSR|4|Silvercut Roadway} förbinder hjärtat av Tal'Dorei-{@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}-till dess avlägsna ytterligheter, och ger handelsmän och resenärer ett visst mått av säkerhet mot vildmarken. Delar av denna urgamla väg föregick {@book Tal'Dorei Council|TDCSR|3|Tal'Dorei Council}, och den går nu från {@book Bladeshimmer Shoreline|TDCSR|4|Bladeshimmer Shoreline} till {@book Lucidian Coast|TDCSR|4|Lucidian Coast}, och förbinder de flesta större civilisationskärnor i landet.

entries.name: Silvercut Crossroads
entries: {@book Silvercut Roadway|TDCSR|4|Silvercut Roadway} och {@book Wildwood Byway|TDCSR|4|Wildwood Byway} möts i skuggan av {@book Ironseat Ridge|TDCSR|4|Ironseat Ridge}. Under {@book Drassig|TDCSR|2|The Iron Rule of Drassig} avrättades många oskyldiga och krigshjältar genom hängning vid en massiv galge som en gång stod vid korsningen, med kroppar upphängda på skyltar som en varning för oliktänkande. Galgen förstördes av {@book Zan Tal'Dorei's|TDCSR|2|Tal'Dorei Ascendant} rebellarmé, och rebellerna skapade ett stenmonument med en inskription för att hedra alla som förlorade sina liv för tyranniet:

Revolutionens fanbärare hedrar de oskyldigt döda. Hämnd kommer inte att återupprätta de förlorades liv, inte heller kommer den att lugna deras själar. Vi lovar att ni kommer att få rättvisa, för rättvisan kommer att se till att inget mer oskyldigt blod ska utgöras.
De flesta resenärer väljer att inte slå läger för nära platsen, eftersom det finns otaliga legender om spöken som omger detta dystra monument.

entries.name: Silvercut Roadway Adventures
entries: Spelmästare som sätter sitt äventyr på {@book Silvercut Roadway|TDCSR|4|Silvercut Roadway} kan använda sig av de här handlingshakarna som inspiration.

entries.name: The Road Warriors (low-level)
entries: När de reser genom Silvercut stöter karaktärerna på det rykande vraket av ett stort vagntåg, och undersökningen visar att det har plundrats efter en våldsam strid. Ett team av legosoldater som kallas Road Warriors ger sig på karaktärerna och anklagar dem för attacken. När man undersöker vraket hittar man oheliga symboler från {@deity The Ruiner|Exandria|TDCSR|Ruiner}, vilket tyder på att {@book Ravagers|TDCSR|5|Ravagers} var ansvariga för massakern, vilket gör att karaktärerna lätt kan rentvå sina namn.

Men är det verkligen så enkelt? Ytterligare undersökningar visar att konvojen hade ett antal legosoldater med magiker i sin mitt, och många av dem hade kontrakt med {@book League of Miracles|TDCSR|3|League of Miracles}.

entries.name: Shard of the Shadebarrow (mid-level)
entries: En {@creature wraith} som kallar sig Archdruid Avandros ande har animerat en armé av {@creature ghoul|MM|ghouls} och {@creature ghast|MM|ghasts} från kyrkogården. De odöda har tagit över {@book Silvercut Crossroads|TDCSR|4|Silvercut Crossroads}, och de måste tas om hand innan en nationell handelskris uppstår. Men vad gör anden från en archdruid från Dawn Circle i den här massgraven? Genom att smyga in på kyrkogården avslöjas en mänsklig skalle med olycksbådande ametistutväxter som sticker ut från benet, och Avandros ande är desperat för att skydda den.

entries.title: Art Credit: {@link Biago D'Alessandro|http://artstation.com/blas-t }
entries.altText: A marshy forest with thick, dark trees, their trunks covered in red mushrooms. Three adventurers stand, weapons drawn, each in blue tunics under silver armor. The man in the back holds a glowing polearm and the man in front aims a longbow as the woman in the middle wields a sword, her right foot illuminated by a glowing white circle of Will-O'-Wisps.

entries.name: Throne of the Arch Heart
entries: I foten av {@book Ironseat Ridge|TDCSR|4|Ironseat Ridge} finns en liten höjd som är känd som {@deity The Arch Heart|Exandria|TDCSR|Arch Heart}: en samlingsplats för de många nomadiska {@book centaurs|TDCSR|7|centaurs} som rider över {@book Dividing Plains|TDCSR|4|Dividing Plains}. {@book centaurs|TDCSR|7|centaurs} föddes först när {@deity The Arch Heart|Exandria|TDCSR|Arch Heart} visade barmhärtighet mot en stam av elviga ryttare som gav sina liv för att tjäna sin gud under {@book Calamity|TDCSR|2|The Calamity}. I århundraden har alla {@book centaurs|TDCSR|7|centaurs} återvänt till {@deity The Arch Heart|Exandria|TDCSR|Arch Heart} tronen en gång per årtionde för att samlas i ett hjordmöte för att diskutera tillståndet för hjordarna och för att hylla sin gudom på den kulle där de första {@book centaurs|TDCSR|7|centaurs} skapades. Denna händelse orsakar stort kaos på de östra slätterna; den massiva migrationen av kentaurhjordarna stör handeln och upprör {@book Ravagers|TDCSR|5|Ravagers} till fruktansvärda hämndaktioner mot {@deity The Arch Heart|Exandria|TDCSR|Arch Heart} - den {@deity The Ruiner|Exandria|TDCSR|Ruiner's} gudomliga nemesisens skapelser.

entries.name: Throne of the Arch Heart Adventures
entries: Spelmästare som utspelar sitt äventyr i Throne of the Arch Heart kan använda den här handlingen som inspiration.

entries.name: Fist of the Ruiner (mid-level)
entries: Många {@book orcs|TDCSR|5|orcs} kallar denna uppkomst för {@deity The Ruiner|Exandria|TDCSR|Ruiner} näven, för även de skapades här i sin guds avbild. Legenden berättar att {@creature orc|MM|orcs} och {@book centaurs|TDCSR|7|centaurs} båda skapades på denna höjd i efterdyningarna av en strid mellan {@deity The Arch Heart|Exandria|TDCSR|Arch Heart} och {@deity The Ruiner|Exandria|TDCSR|Ruiner}. {@book Orcs|TDCSR|5|orcs} med en djup uppskattning för gamla myter från hela Tal'Dorei gör en pilgrimsresa vid tiden för Herdsmeet. En del är långvariga vänner till {@book centaurs|TDCSR|7|centaurs}, och de hyllar {@deity The Arch Heart|Exandria|TDCSR|Arch Heart} tillsammans som tack för att de spillde det blod som skapade dem. Andra {@book orcs|TDCSR|5|orcs} förenar sig med {@book Ravagers|TDCSR|5|Ravagers} för att belägra Herdsmeet - och {@book Ravagers'|TDCSR|5|Ravagers} blodtörstiga makt är så stor att {@creature orc|MM|orcs} och {@book centaurs|TDCSR|7|centaurs} har börjat anlita humanoida legosoldater för att försvara hjordarna och pilgrimerna när de försöker dyrka {@deity The Arch Heart|Exandria|TDCSR|Arch Heart} i fred.

entries.name: Torian Forest
entries: Torian Forest ligger i den sydvästra kanten av Cliffkeep Mountain Range och levererar mycket {@book Emon's|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} timmer och {@book Kraghammer's|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} ved. Även om lokalbefolkningen stolt proklamerar att Torian-skogen är den "mest välkomnande" och "minst hemsökta" av Tal'Doreis skogar, är detta mer av en myt än vad folk tror. Skogen är välkomnande och ljus i sina kanter, med en vacker våtmark i dess norra ände, men i dess djupa och outforskade hjärta finns andar som inte har förståtts sedan {@book Age of Arcanum|TDCSR|2|Age of Arcanum}-och en grym och hungrig {@creature wraithroot tree|TDCSR} som vaktar en magisk artefakt som likaså inte har setts sedan urminnes tider.

entries.name: Rivermaw Herd
entries: Rivermaw föddes ur de vilda folken i {@book Dividing Plains|TDCSR|4|Dividing Plains}, fria människor som undvek samhällets begränsningar, och är den största av {@book Dividing Plains'|TDCSR|4|Dividing Plains} hjordarna. Den har nu nästan tio tusen medlemmar, tillsammans med ett antal satellitflockar som är lojala mot Rivermaw.

Även om Rivermaw nu är en mäktig kraft för det goda i {@book Dividing Plains|TDCSR|4|Dividing Plains}, hade de en blygsam början. För bara två generationer sedan var de inte mycket mer än trehundra {@book half-giants|TDCSR|5|Half-Giants}, {@book orcs|TDCSR|5|orcs}, {@book gnolls|TDCSR|7|gnolls}, {@book humans|TDCSR|5|humans} och nomader av andra raser som bodde i Torian Forest.

Det var inte förrän de erövrades av Herd of Storms, med den tyranniska goliaten Kevdak i spetsen, som ett mer våldsamt sätt att leva tvingades på dem under ett antal år. När Kevdak väl var dödad, tog de återstående medlemmarna av både Rivermaw och Herd of Storms avstånd från hans brutala sätt att leva och blev den {@book Rivermaw herd|TDCSR|4|Rivermaw Herd} som är känd över hela Tal'Dorei idag. Den leds av två {@book goliaths|TDCSR|5|Half-Giants}: Zanroar, son till Kevdak, och Skyhaal, dotter till Zanroar.

entries.name: Turst Fields

items.name: Village:
entries: Befolkning 2 420 (40% {@book humans|TDCSR|5|humans}, 38% {@book halflings|TDCSR|5|halflings}, 15% {@book gnolls|TDCSR|7|gnolls}, 8% {@book other races|TDCSR|5|Other Races})

Nordväst om {@book Drynna|TDCSR|4|Drynna}, inte långt från Dawnmist Pines, arbetar jordbrukssamhället Turst Fields på extremt bördig mark som matas av {@book Mooren River Run|TDCSR|4|Mooren River Run}. Samhället tillhandahåller mycket av Tal'Dorei och {@book Whitestone's|TDCSR|4|Whitestone} odlad mat och produkter, men måste importera de flesta andra varor utom trä, vilket gör det till ett lukrativt stopp för handelskaravaner som reser längs Parchwood Way till {@book Drynna|TDCSR|4|Drynna} - och ett lätt mål för bedragare. Därför är nästan tvåhundra sköldar från {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun} permanent stationerade här för att bevara freden och förhindra olaglig verksamhet. Nästan lika vanligt som ankomsten av en handelsvagn är en bepansrad vagn som transporterar rånare, bedragare och hästtjuvar tillbaka till {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun} för rättegång.

entries.name: Gnoll Mercy
entries: {@book Turst Fields|TDCSR|4|Turst Fields} har en betydande {@creature gnoll|MM} befolkning. Som muterade varelser som skapats genom demoniska ritualer undviks {@creature gnoll|MM|gnolls} som monster i de flesta humanoida bosättningar på {@book Dividing Plains|TDCSR|4|Dividing Plains}. Utan Dustpaw {@creature gnoll|MM|gnolls} skulle Turst ändå inte ha överlevt sin första sommar. När byn grundades var den ett lätt byte för {@book Ravagers|TDCSR|5|Ravagers}. Deras ledare begärde en blodtribut från folket i Turst, men byborna vägrade att offra ett offer. Den här cellen av {@book Ravagers|TDCSR|5|Ravagers} hade nyligen sökt slaktarens demonherres gunst och förvandlade ett antal av de slättboende hyenorna till {@creature gnoll|MM|gnolls} i den strävan.

När byborna i Turst vägrade att ge upp sina egna, släppte {@book Ravagers|TDCSR|5|Ravagers} loss {@creature gnoll|MM|gnolls} på dem. Men något ovanligt hände. Efter att {@creature gnoll|MM|gnolls} först hade dragit blod började en av dem gråta. Sedan en annan, tills alla {@creature gnoll|MM|gnolls} ylade av sorg och ilska. Dessa varelser, trots att de var genomsyrade av demonisk ichor, vände sig mot sina skapare för att försvara sitt hjälplösa byte.

Än idag har Dustpaw {@creature gnoll|MM|gnolls} stannat kvar i Turst och långsamt blivit pålitliga medlemmar i samhället. Deras oroväckande huggtänder och hundansikten upprör många som reser till byn, men alla som hånar {@creature gnoll|MM|gnolls} gör det på egen risk. Inte för att de riskerar att bli misshandlade av en {@creature gnoll|MM} - även om alla humanoida varelser slår tillbaka om de drivs för långt - utan för att hatiska uppviglare snart kommer att finna sig omringade av Turst-militärens spjut.

entries.name: Turst Fields Adventures
entries: Spelmästare som utspelar sitt äventyr i {@book Turst Fields|TDCSR|4|Turst Fields} kan använda denna intrigkrok som inspiration.

entries.name: Herd Mentality (mid-level)
entries: En halvälv, halv{@book dragonblood|TDCSR|5|dragonblood} {@creature Ravager slaughter lord|TDCSR} {@homebrew |(see page 249)} som kallar sig Grud the Great har tagit kontroll över en arm av {@book Ravagers|TDCSR|5|Ravagers}. Hennes högt organiserade regemente dyrkar {@deity The Strife Emperor|Exandria|TDCSR|Strife Emperor}. Nu marscherar de mot Turst för att ta ett lätt fotfäste på de norra slätterna. Armén är för stor för att stoppas av bara karaktärerna, men en Dustpaw {@creature gnoll|MM} krigare vid namn Akaksa känner till ett antal nomadiska grupper som vandrar i närheten och som skulle kunna hjälpa till att försvara staden, om de övertalas på rätt sätt. Karaktärerna kan söka upp Dawnmist Herd, som leds av en goliath {@creature Rivermaw stormborn|TDCSR} {@homebrew |(see page 253)} vid namn Gardessk, och övertyga honom om att hjälpa folket i Turst.

entries.name: Westruun

items.name: City:
entries: Befolkning 51 980 (61% {@book humans|TDCSR|5|humans}, 10% {@book gnomes|TDCSR|5|gnomes}, 7% {@book tieflings|TDCSR|5|tieflings}, 5% {@book orcs|TDCSR|5|orcs}, 4% {@book half-giants|TDCSR|5|Half-Giants}, 1% {@book gnolls|TDCSR|7|gnolls}, 12% {@book other races|TDCSR|5|Other Races})

Staden Westruun är centrum för Tal'Dorei, en kulturell korsningspunkt längs {@book Silvercut Roadway|TDCSR|4|Silvercut Roadway} som välkomnar äventyrare, handelsmän och vagabonder av alla slag. Trots sitt namn ligger Westruun mer öster än väster, och är i själva verket uppkallad efter Palest Westruun, handelsmannen och filosofen som grundade staden. Westruun led under goliatyrannen Kevdaks Herd of Storms styre. Ännu värre var att dess avlägsna städer och stora stenbyggnader härjades av Umbrasyl hoppförstöraren Umbrasyls sura andedräkt, en {@creature ancient black dragon} av {@book Chroma Conclave|TDCSR|2|The Chroma Conclave} som krävde tribut från sin lya i det kusliga berget {@book Gatshadow|TDCSR|4|Gatshadow}. Trots den skada som dess onda härskare åsamkade Westruun var en av de första städerna i Tal'Dorei som återhämtade sig från {@book Conclave|TDCSR|2|The Chroma Conclave}. Även om dess regering är djupt skuldsatt till både {@book League of Miracles|TDCSR|3|League of Miracles} och ett antal äventyrare har staden sedan länge återtagit sin plats som en ekonomisk, akademisk och politisk makt inom Tal'Dorei.

entries.name: Government
entries: {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun} genomgick en politisk revolution efter {@book Chroma Conclave's|TDCSR|2|The Chroma Conclave} nederlaget. Den tidigare markgreven Brandon Zimmerset var en tyrann som krävde absolut makt för sig själv efter Kevdaks nederlag mot Vox Machina. Titeln som markgreve är en kvarleva från det auktoritära styret av Warren {@book Drassig|TDCSR|2|The Iron Rule of Drassig} för flera hundra år sedan, och de som innehar detta ämbete utses på livstid av rådet. En grupp lokala idealister som kallas Retrievers gick samman med äventyrare och legosoldater för att störta Zimmerset ett decennium efter att han tog makten, och insatte sin ledare som lordborgmästare i stället. Val till posten som borgmästare i {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun} hålls vart femte år, utan tidsbegränsning. Alla vuxna medborgare i staden som har bott där i minst fem år har rösträtt, även om endast en bråkdel av folket faktiskt använder den.

Retrieverna fortsätter att vara en politisk kraft i {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun}, och flera av {@book Westruun's|TDCSR|4|Westruun} delegaterna till {@book Tal'Dorei Council|TDCSR|3|Tal'Dorei Council} är medlemmar av denna fraktion. De bedriver en kampanj för att avskaffa markgreveämbetet i alla bosättningar i Tal'Dorei. Även om de har ett brett stöd i rådet har rådet inte befogenhet att ensidigt kräva att de ingående stadsstaterna ändrar sitt regeringssystem. De revolutionärt sinnade Retrieverna kvävs något av behovet av att kompromissa med andra städer.

Borgmästare Lysandra Kallos är en medelålders goliat och tidigare ledare för Retrievers. Hon har aldrig förlorat en röst för omval och har verkställande makt över stadens försvar, tillsammans med förmågan att upplösa alla företag eller gillen och att förvisa alla personer eller grupper på upp till tio personer från staden efter eget gottfinnande. Hon styr {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun} med hjälp av ett råd av tio rådgivare.

entries.name: Defense
entries: Borgmästaren leder en stadsvakt på cirka 1 200 tränade soldater som kallas för slättens sköldar, även om de flesta bara kallar dem för sköldarna. {@book Westruun's|TDCSR|4|Westruun} soldaterna är utspridda över själva stadens murar, stationerade vid portarna till dussintals avlägsna bosättningar och genomför räder mot små celler av {@book Ravagers|TDCSR|5|Ravagers} över slätten.

Många människor i staden skulle vilja samla sina styrkor och sätta stopp för {@book Ravagers'|TDCSR|5|Ravagers} dödskulten en gång för alla, men sköldarna är alltför spridda för att kunna starta en effektiv offensiv. Även i sitt nuvarande tillstånd passerar dussintals - om inte hundratals - legosoldater, prisjägare och äventyrare genom {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun} varje år i jakt på blodigt arbete som sköldarna är för belägrade för att hantera själva.

entries.name: Debt
entries: Innan han avsattes godkände markgreve Brandon Zimmerset hundratals återuppbyggnadspengar - erbjudanden om guld till alla som kunde återuppbygga de enorma skador som staden drabbades av under Umbrasyls angrepp och Stormarnas flockars ockupation av staden. Belöningarna lades på stadens belägringsbrytande stenmurar, majestätiska torn och parapeter och till och med på stadens ikoniska stolp- och bjälklagshus, av vilka många raserades helt och hållet under angreppet.

Markgreven förväntade sig att dessa prispengar skulle slutföras långsamt under årtionden, men de togs upp och slutfördes på några få år av legosoldater som tjänade en grupp som kallades {@book League of Miracles|TDCSR|3|League of Miracles} {@homebrew |(see page 56)}. Markgreven sattes med en förkrossande skuld, en skuld som han både var ovillig och oförmögen att betala innan han blev fördriven av Retrievers. Som hans efterträdare ärvde borgmästare Lysandra Kallos Zimmersets enorma skuld till {@book League|TDCSR|3|League of Miracles}, och hon försöker ständigt hitta sätt att lätta på trycket från dem - särskilt som ligan fortsätter att använda skulden som påtryckningsmedel för att köpa lojalitet från hennes rådgivande råd.

entries.name: Crime
entries: {@book Clasp|TDCSR|3|The Clasp} har blivit en viktig och offentlig kraft i {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun} sedan den kriminella organisationens tvivelaktigt dygdiga makeover efter {@book Cinder King's|TDCSR|2|Thordak, the Cinder King} nederlaget i {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}. Många {@book Clasp|TDCSR|3|The Clasp}-agenter har rykte om sig att vara folkhjältar över hela {@book Dividing Plains|TDCSR|4|Dividing Plains} och gör offentliga framträdanden på tavernor och torg i hela {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun}.

Faktum kvarstår dock att {@book Clasp|TDCSR|3|The Clasp} fortfarande är en kriminell organisation. De har kontrollerat och effektivt bedrivit sin skumma verksamhet i årtionden rakt framför näsan på Shields. Deras nätverk av stängsel går från kust till kust, {@book Stilben|TDCSR|4|Stilben} till {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}. Deras gömställe byts ut med några års mellanrum, när Shields lyckas spåra upp dem. Deras nuvarande gömställe är hemlighållet bakom skyltfönstret till Saddled Plainscow, en populär krog som ägs och drivs av {@book Clasp|TDCSR|3|The Clasp} agenter.

Grinarna får ibland ett dåligt rykte i {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun}, eftersom människor behöver hjälp varje dag, men Grinarna föredrar att vänta på precis rätt ögonblick för att avslöja sig själva och slå till mot ondskan.

entries.name: Geography
entries: Miltals av åkermark och fält omger {@book Westruun's|TDCSR|4|Westruun} höga stenmurar - utom i väster, där staden gränsar till {@book Bramblewood|TDCSR|4|The Bramblewood} och överskuggas av den dimmiga toppen av {@book Gatshadow|TDCSR|4|Gatshadow}. Nästan två dussin byar och städer omger stadens murar.
Stadens inre är indelat i sex distrikt:

entries.name: Scholar Ward
entries: Stadens lilla södra avdelning är full av stora tempel för {@book Prime Deities|TDCSR|3|Prime Deities} och bostäder för deras präster. De viktigaste gudarna för {@book Dividing Plains|TDCSR|4|Dividing Plains} är {@deity The Lawbearer|Exandria|TDCSR|Lawbearer}, {@deity The Wildmother|Exandria|TDCSR|Wildmother} och {@deity The Platinum Dragon|Exandria|TDCSR|Platinum Dragon}, och det framgår tydligt av deras enorma, praktfulla helgedomar i tempelavdelningen. De största templen här är den första bastionen, den vilda trädgården och {@deity The Platinum Dragon|Exandria|TDCSR|Platinum Dragon's} vilan.

entries.name: Opal Ward
entries: {@book Westruun's|TDCSR|4|Westruun} centrala stadsdelen är också dess kommunala hjärta. I stadsdelen finns inga bostäder, men där finns borgmästarens residens, {@book Hall of Reason|TDCSR|4|6. Hall of Reason} och det offentliga torget.

entries.name: Residential Ward
entries: Den nordöstra delen av {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun} är stadens mest tätbefolkade stadsdel, där mer än två tredjedelar av befolkningen bor. Det finns inga större landmärken i denna avdelning, även om varje kvarter i avdelningen har sin egen unika kultur. Även om turister kanske inte besöker landmärkena här finns det otaliga lokala bagerier, butiker och pubar som är älskade av invånarna.

Den här avdelningen är full av brottslighet. {@book Westruun's|TDCSR|4|Westruun} fattigaste invånarna är trängda i trånga kvarter, ibland så lite som ett enda kvarter från stadens rikaste herrgårdar. {@book Clasp|TDCSR|3|The Clasp} och {@book Myriad|TDCSR|3|The Myriad} utnyttjar både fattiga och välbärgade, och underblåser ofta de spänningar som drabbar stadens nedtryckta för att skapa kaos som döljer deras brott. Sköldarna är alltför tunt bemannade för att kunna ta itu med dessa uppviglare på rätt sätt. Till skillnad från i Temple Ward är religionsfrihet inte en garanterad rättighet här, inte ens i det egna hemmets avskildhet. Även om {@deity The Lawbearer|Exandria|TDCSR|Lawbearer}, {@deity The Wildmother|Exandria|TDCSR|Wildmother} och {@deity The Platinum Dragon|Exandria|TDCSR|Platinum Dragon} alla är välvilliga gudar är många av deras {@book Westruunian|TDCSR|4|Westruun} anhängare inte särskilt toleranta mot andra trosriktningar.

entries.name: Market Ward
entries: {@book Westruun's|TDCSR|4|Westruun} sydvästra avdelningen innehåller majoriteten av dess företag, handelsbodar och produktionslager. En del av dessa företag är historiska inventarier i staden, återuppbyggda av {@book League of Miracles|TDCSR|3|League of Miracles} under tidigare år, men många säljer överprisade varor för att tillgodose turister, äventyrare och stadens rika elit.

Det är för närvarande modernt för butiksägare att bo på en andra våning ovanför sina butiker, även om mindre skrupelfria affärsmän har förvandlat sina bostäder till spelhålor, svarta marknader och illegala bordeller. Den mest betydelsefulla byggnaden i denna avdelning är Exandrian Exchange, ett marmorväggigt auktionshus där hundratals försäljare säljer sällsynta och ovanliga föremål från hela Tal'Dorei. En satellitplats för {@book Gilmore's Glorious Goods|TDCSR|4|14. Gilmore's Glorious Goods}, en berömd butik för magiska föremål i {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}, är en älskad attraktion i detta distrikt.

entries.name: Underwalk Ward
entries: Stadens nyaste avdelning ligger under jorden. Det är en förlängning av bostadsområdet som byggs av omarbetade delar av avloppen, underjordiska militära bunkrar och vinkällare från herrgårdar som förstörts av Umbrasyl och Herd of Storms.

Underwalk grävdes frenetiskt ut under invasionen av {@book Chroma Conclave|TDCSR|2|The Chroma Conclave} i hopp om att hålla befolkningen gömd. Den har i stort sett varit övergiven under de senaste 24 åren, utom för dem som är för fattiga för att återvända till bostadsområdet, men under de senaste två åren har man försökt skapa ett unikt och levande ekosystem i Underwalk. De optimistiska entreprenörer som försöker popularisera bostäderna i Underwalk anställer äventyrare i stora mängder, för varje dag sprids nya och oroande rykten om månghövdade monstruositeter som vandrar runt i Underwalks skuggiga vägar till ytan. Den mest kända ingången till detta virrvarr av tunnlar är Underwalk Gates, en fyrtio fot bred trappa i bostadsavdelningen som går ner i en gapande öppning som endast lyses upp av fackelljus. En annan ingång som mest är känd av {@book Clasp|TDCSR|3|The Clasp} är en enda anspråkslös schaktgrop i Opal Ward, med ett metalllock med {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun}:s vapen på.

entries.name: Points of Interest
entries: The City of {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun} has a number of noteworthy landmarks. They are keyed to the map of {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun}.

entries.title: The City of Westruun
entries.altText: A map of the city of Westruun, showing a cross-section of the city at the edge of a forest as well as a smaller map of the Underwalk Ward.

entries: {@note Art Credit: {@link Kent Davis|http://artstation.com/idrawbagman}}

entries.name: 1. Cobalt Reserve
entries: This vast repository looks more like a house of worship than a library. Nevertheless, this landmark of the Scholar Ward is Tal'Dorei's largest house of knowledge, and it is maintained and fiercely defended by the monks of the {@book Library of the Cobalt Soul|TDCSR|3|Library of the Cobalt Soul} {@homebrew |(see page 58)}.

A character who spends 1 hour in the public section of the Cobalt Reserve can make a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill History}) check, discovering any piece of common knowledge in Tal'Dorei. On a failure, this check can be repeated after another hour of study. The GM can decide that the knowledge the character seeks can only be found in the restricted archives, which only members of the {@book Cobalt Soul|TDCSR|3|Library of the Cobalt Soul}, or characters in the {@book Cobalt Soul's|TDCSR|3|Library of the Cobalt Soul} good graces, can access.

entries.name: 2. Westhall Academy
entries: No university in Tal'Dorei can hope to compete with the prestige of {@book Emon's|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} {@book Alabaster Lyceum|TDCSR|4|5. Alabaster Lyceum}, but the Westhall Academy does its best. Its sand-colored stone walls and copper-patina dome are an unmistakable landmark of the Scholar Ward. They imply a stately and refined institution with an unpretentious, workaday attitude. Most of the Westhall Academy's students come from humble backgrounds, and the lord mayor does her level best to ensure that the academy is funded enough to let anyone from the plains who shows great promise attend, free of cost. Mages, architects, poets, artists, agriculturalists, and people of all disciplines can find an education at Westhall.

entries.name: 3. Yuminor Observatory
entries: {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun} is a fairly flat city, and one tower on the edge of the Scholar Ward looms high above the nearby {@book Westhall Academy in Westruun|TDCSR|4|2. Westhall Academy}. It looks forever skyward, the arcanists inside constantly charting the movements of the heavens. A quasi-religious order of diviners and astromancers named the Scions of Yuminor study here, supported by the academy's headmistress, Estella Ladimar, who is herself a blood descendant of the heroic wizard Atz Yuminor. The observatory is open to all, and the diviners here will gladly give a star reading for 10 gp, once per day. Receiving this reading allows you to roll {@dice 1d20}. Note the result—you can exchange it for any {@dice d20} roll made by a creature you can see. This divination fades after 24 hours. Despite the Scions of Yuminor's affability, something seems odd about them, like they have stared into the stars just a bit too long and seen something they wish they could forget.

entries.title: Art Credit: {@link Kent Davis|http://artstation.com/idrawbagman}
entries.altText: A red cloaked individual looks toward a massive, tall tower with a golden spherical observatory affixed to it's top, consisting of an intricate telescope housed in a gyroscopic apparatus. Behind the tower loom large, snowy mountains in a purple, dusky sky.

entries.name: 4. First Bastion
entries: The most magnificent of the temples within {@book Westruun's|TDCSR|4|Westruun} Temple Ward is the First Bastion. Dedicated to the {@deity The Lawbearer|Exandria|TDCSR|Lawbearer}, this opulent sanctuary is a common attraction for visiting folk of all faiths. Its magnificent, even decadent, gold-and-marble exterior is a sight most people can't imagine exists upon the Material Plane—it seems like nothing less than a building from the realm of the gods themselves. The First Bastion was a secret home for refugees during Kevdak's occupation, and many {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun} survivors have turned to the faith of the {@deity The Lawbearer|Exandria|TDCSR|Lawbearer} after being protected by her grace.

entries.name: 5. Lord Mayor's Residence
entries: The Lord Mayor's Residence is a squat manor in the Opal Ward. It was originally named the Margrave's Keep, and as such, it is a defensible and highly fortified compound buttressed against military barracks. The interior has been livened up significantly by the lord mayor, but the exterior is still a spare, military edifice.

entries.name: 6. Hall of Reason
entries: This beautiful courthouse in the Opal Ward is constructed in sweeping Lyrengornian style and bears a marble statue of the {@deity The Platinum Dragon|Exandria|TDCSR|Platinum Dragon} above its steps. The square before the courtroom steps is a forum for public gatherings and bears a fountain depicting Palest Westruun, the founder of the city, atop an onyx horse.

entries.name: 7. The Black King
entries: Palest Westruun was not a king, but his new statue in the Opal Ward is often called the {@creature Black King|TDCSR}, a subtle jab at the city's previous "Black King," the tyrannical dragon Umbrasyl. The high priest of the First Bastion blessed both the {@creature Black King|TDCSR} and {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun} itself when the statue was unveiled on the anniversary of {@book Westruun's|TDCSR|4|Westruun} reclamation, saying, "May the {@deity The Lawbearer|Exandria|TDCSR|Lawbearer} grant us all strength of spirit when chaos next threatens our peaceful civilization. When that time comes, may the {@creature Black King|TDCSR} unsheathe his sword to rally our people and lead {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun} to victory."

When the safety of all of {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun} is threatened, the {@creature Black King|TDCSR} will animate and defend its people, becoming a {@creature Black King|TDCSR|stone golem with a speed of 60 feet, Charisma and Intelligence scores of 18 (+4), and the ability to speak Common}. Its personality is dour but determined—regal and single-minded in its desire to protect its city and its people.

entries.name: 8. Survivors' Legacy
entries: The names of all those in {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun} who survived the reign of Kevdak and Umbrasyl are carved on a wall in the first chamber of the Underwalk. Legend has it that the memorial was created by {@creature Percival de Rolo|TDCSR|Percival de Rolo} when the people of {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun} first hid here from the wrath of the {@book Chroma Conclave|TDCSR|2|The Chroma Conclave} after Umbrasyl's death, but it has been expanded in the years since, now including the names of all who perished in the struggle as well.

The Survivors' Legacy is a symbol of hope, warding away the sorrow and evil of the Underwalk beneath, and to this day common, folk make trips here to honor their lost loved ones. Some of the more generous folk give aid to the homeless living here as well, and some more adventurous travelers make prayers to the {@deity The Dawnfather|Exandria|TDCSR|Dawnfather} and the {@deity The Matron of Ravens|Exandria|TDCSR|Matron of Ravens} here before delving into the Underwalk's deeper reaches.

Once per week, a character related to one of the people named on the Survivors' Legacy can pray there and gain {@quickref Advantage and Disadvantage|PHB|2|0|advantage} on death {@quickref saving throws|PHB|2|1} for the next 24 hours.

entries.name: Westruun Adventures
entries: Game Masters who set their adventure in {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun} can use these plot hooks for inspiration.

entries.name: They Can't Have Flown Away (low-level)
entries: Over the past week, over four dozen {@creature plainscow|TDCSR|plainscows} {@homebrew |(see page 248)}, exceptional livestock and beasts of burden, have disappeared from {@book Westruun's|TDCSR|4|Westruun} outlying villages. Left in their place were nothing but a series of five-foot holes in the ground and traces of acid scarring. Farmers and caravanners alike are frightened and confused; these recurring attacks threaten to destroy {@book Westruun's|TDCSR|4|Westruun} agriculture and disrupt commerce. Jeremiah Sook, head of the regional Rancher's Guild, is willing to pay a hefty bounty for the culprits.

entries.name: An Assistant's Plight (mid-level)
entries: Just outside {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun} is Slaterock Tower, the abode of renowned archmage {@book Realmseer Eskil Ryndarien|TDCSR|3|Realmseer Eskil Ryndarien} {@homebrew |(see page 48)}. Normally, none are invited to the tower, but the characters, wherever they may be, receive a missive from the Realmseer's assistant, Jekt. The letter claims the Realmseer has gone missing within the tower, and the building itself now bars Jekt's entry—and apparently, the Realmseer's exit. Upon arrival, and confirmation of Jekt's request, the tower seems to constantly shift its interior structure, almost acting like a sentient entity. Challenge after deadly challenge is thrown at the party as they traverse the labyrinthine paths of the tower, only to find that the Realmseer himself is actually trying to keep something far more dangerous imprisoned within.

entries.name: The Stuff of Nightmares (mid-level)
entries: Reports of missing children rise once again within {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun}, with a seemingly unrelated scourge of nightmares plaguing people old and young alike. Mystic expertise is sought to acquire information regarding either issue, but the sadistic {@creature oni}, secretly responsible for both, is deft at erasing its tracks. Nyx and Vryll, twin tiefling mages with only a single horn each, have also recently opened a dream-reading stall, and their business is booming. Are they responsible, or is their exploitative business just a red herring?

entries.name: Down Below (high-level)
entries: A massive sinkhole has emerged beneath the First Bastion, taking a portion of the temple into the darkness of the Underwalk Ward. With the depth seemingly bottomless, and initial investigators going missing, high priest Umentu Helmdoff seeks the assistance of brave and able-bodied adventurers to find answers and save the people still in the temple when it vanished. Only one thing is certain when descending into the unknown below—the terror only grows as the light from above fades.

entries.name: Wildwood Byway
entries: Known as the oldest road in Tal'Dorei, this path linked the adolescent cities of {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} and {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} before the landfall of humankind. During the reign of {@book Drassig|TDCSR|2|The Iron Rule of Drassig}, the {@book Silvercut Roadway|TDCSR|4|Silvercut Roadway} intersected with this ancient road. Warren {@book Drassig|TDCSR|2|The Iron Rule of Drassig} built countless fortifications along this road to defend his holdings against {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn}, a move that made him many allies within {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer}.

While traveling the Wildwood in broad daylight isn't any more dangerous than riding along the Silvercut, it's common knowledge that the forest at the northern end of this road is fraught with danger. Wild beasts, cultists, and bandits make the Wildwood their home.

entries.name: Cliffkeep Mountains
entries: Spanning the northern reaches of Tal'Dorei, the {@book Cliffkeep Mountains|TDCSR|4|Cliffkeep Mountains} are an impenetrable barrier between the Republic of Tal'Dorei and the frozen {@book Neverfields|TDCSR|4|The Neverfields}. The southern foothills are dotted with forests and pockets of civilization, standing resolute against the unwelcoming topography. Deep within the earth itself, the dwarven stronghold of {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} flourishes and expands, just a few scant leagues above ancient caverns that plunge into a domain of unknowable horrors.

The {@book Cliffkeeps|TDCSR|4|Cliffkeep Mountains} are the largest mountain range in all of Tal'Dorei, and innumerable types of beings make their homes upon the crags, in mountainside caves, and in the miles upon miles of tunnels that descend into the earth below them. {@book Dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves}, {@book half-giants|TDCSR|5|Half-Giants}, {@book goblins|TDCSR|5|goblinkin}, and kobolds are the best-known peoples of the {@book Cliffkeeps|TDCSR|4|Cliffkeep Mountains}, but the mountains are also home to the fire giants of {@book Vulkanon|TDCSR|7|Fire Giants}, wandering {@creature ettin|MM|ettins} and {@creature hill giant|MM|hill giants}, hungry {@creature cyclops|MM|cyclopes}, {@creature frost giant} marauders from the {@book Neverfields|TDCSR|4|The Neverfields}, and cave-dwelling {@creature troll|MM|trolls}.

Near the earth elemental rift and {@book the Ashari|TDCSR|3|The Ashari} village of {@book Terrah|TDCSR|4|Terrah}, the mountains themselves seem to rise up in defense as {@creature earth elemental|MM|earth elementals} spring from the living stones. Northward, peaks reach higher and winds grow colder as snow and ice take the lands to become the frozen waste of the {@book Neverfields|TDCSR|4|The Neverfields}. These challenges keep the common folk at bay, the secrets and spoils held within these crags calling to the brave, the clever, and the foolhardy.

entries.title:
The Cliffkeep Mountains
Art Credit: {@link Andy Law|http://artstation.com/andylaw1}

items.name: Majority Faiths:
entries: {@deity The All-Hammer|Exandria|TDCSR|All-Hammer}, {@deity The Stormlord|Exandria|TDCSR|Stormlord}, {@deity The Dawnfather|Exandria|TDCSR|Dawnfather}

items.name: Minority Faiths:
entries: {@deity The Platinum Dragon|Exandria|TDCSR|Platinum Dragon}, {@deity The Moonweaver|Exandria|TDCSR|Moonweaver}, {@deity The Lord of the Hells|Exandria|TDCSR|Lord of the Hells}, {@deity The Scaled Tyrant|Exandria|TDCSR|Scaled Tyrant}

items.name: Imports:
entries: Lumber, spices, {@creature fish|GoS}, grain, livestock

items.name: Exports:
entries: Precious gems, industrial metals, {@item quartz}, granite, {@item gold|PHB}, {@item silver|PHB}, {@item platinum|PHB}, mithral, cobalt, jewelry, fungal produce, weapons, armor

entries.name: Fort Daxio
entries: Nestled within the {@book Othendin Pass|TDCSR|4|Othendin Pass}, north of {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}, {@book Fort Daxio|TDCSR|4|Fort Daxio} is a massive stronghold and series of military structures that, under the rule of the {@book Tal'Dorei Council|TDCSR|3|Tal'Dorei Council}, trains Tal'Dorei's most elite warriors. The fortress was constructed following the {@book Scattered War|TDCSR|2|The Scattered War} as a strategic bulwark against opportunistic humanoid and giant bandit forces in the {@book Cliffkeep Mountains|TDCSR|4|Cliffkeep Mountains}, and as a hidden reserve of military might in the event that {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} was ever threatened.

Though Tal'Dorei doesn't maintain a standing army—rather, it assembles one in times of strife from mercenaries, adventurers, and local militias—the forces of {@book Fort Daxio|TDCSR|4|Fort Daxio} are an exception. The legendary Daxio Outriders are a corps of cavaliers some four thousand strong. Half their forces remain stationed in {@book Fort Daxio|TDCSR|4|Fort Daxio} and its surroundings at any given time, serving as a historic barrier between {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} and the bandits and creatures of the {@book Cliffkeep Mountains|TDCSR|4|Cliffkeep Mountains}. The other two thousand Outriders are spread across the continent, typically in battalions of up to one hundred riders, safeguarding villages, patrolling the {@book Silvercut Roadway|TDCSR|4|Silvercut Roadway}, putting pressure on the {@book Ravagers|TDCSR|5|Ravagers} of the {@book Dividing Plains|TDCSR|4|Dividing Plains}, or protecting traveling diplomats.

{@book Fort Daxio|TDCSR|4|Fort Daxio} itself is led by General Elle Gorgofon, a dour but diplomatic tactician. She served faithfully under the fort's previous leader, Warmaster Mikael Daxio, for nearly thirty-five years before he was killed at the hands of a {@creature vampire} hoping to throw the fort into chaos. Daxio was resurrected, but is enjoying an extended holiday in {@book Syngorn|TDCSR|4|Syngorn} rather than returning to arms.

The Daxio Outriders are divided into four different regiments: The Dusk Regiment, the Gale Regiment, the Aegis Regiment, and the Tide Regiment. Each regiment is led by their own assigned general, all answering directly to General Gorgofon (who in turn answers to the Master of War on the {@book Tal'Dorei Council|TDCSR|3|Tal'Dorei Council} in times of conflict).

The Dusk Regiment is responsible for covert operations across the country and is led by General Fei Yujian, a cheerful, affable man. The Gale Regiment is trained in skyborne combat in addition to horse-riding; after the {@book Chroma Conclave|TDCSR|2|The Chroma Conclave} was defeated, {@book Fort Daxio|TDCSR|4|Fort Daxio} trained a variety of {@creature griffon|MM|griffons}, {@creature hippogriff|MM|hippogriffs}, and {@creature wyvern|MM|wyverns} to ward against airborne threats. It is led by General Jillian Sylph, a calm, tactical human with air {@book elemental ancestry|TDCSR|5|Elemental Ancestry}. The Aegis Regiment is charged with remaining in {@book Fort Daxio|TDCSR|4|Fort Daxio} to protect {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}, and is led by General Elle Gorgofon herself. The Tide Regiment is trained in spellcasting and ship-to-ship combat, in case {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} is ever threatened from the western seas. This final regiment is led by General Kay Clearsight, a half-elf trained in the arcane arts at the renowned Soltryce Academy in the Dwendalian Empire of {@book Wildemount|TDCSR|4|Wildemount}.

entries.name: Fort Daxio Adventures
entries: Game Masters who set their adventure in {@book Fort Daxio|TDCSR|4|Fort Daxio} can use this plot hook for inspiration.

entries.name: Vampire Hunters (high-level)
entries: Years ago, Warmaster Mikael Daxio was killed by a {@creature vampire} named Vrylaska Fellbranch. She disappeared without a trace, and the Daxio Outriders have been searching fruitlessly for her for years. While the characters are in {@book Fort Daxio|TDCSR|4|Fort Daxio}, a scout returns with breathless news of vampire attacks in remote settlements in the {@book Cliffkeep Mountains|TDCSR|4|Cliffkeep Mountains}. General Elle Gorgofon suspects a trap, but has no choice but to mobilize the Aegis Regiment—and the characters, if they accept her offer of 5,000 gp—to hunt the monster down.
Little do they know that, while the Aegis Regiment is away, the vampire's minions hidden in {@book Fort Daxio|TDCSR|4|Fort Daxio} will come out to play.

entries.name: Gatshadow
entries: The mighty mountain known as {@book Gatshadow|TDCSR|4|Gatshadow} is a spire of death that looms over the {@book Dividing Plains|TDCSR|4|Dividing Plains}. {@book Westruun|TDCSR|4|Westruun} sees it always upon the horizon, and the most vicious monsters of the {@book Bramblewood|TDCSR|4|The Bramblewood} grow cruel in its fell shadow. Folkloric tales about the evil powers within {@book Gatshadow|TDCSR|4|Gatshadow} are told in all cultures of the {@book Dividing Plains|TDCSR|4|Dividing Plains}: stories of {@creature giant spider|MM|giant spiders} in the forest, of beings of pure shadow that dwell within the mountain's tunnels, and of the tunnels themselves, which are so labyrinthine and shifting that no one who enters will ever escape. These days, most of these stories are told to keep children from wandering into the forest alone—but they are far from simply children's tales.

{@book Gatshadow|TDCSR|4|Gatshadow} was transformed into a place of evil in the {@book Age of Arcanum|TDCSR|2|Age of Arcanum}. Acek Orattim, a priest of the Betrayer God known as the {@deity The Chained Oblivion|Exandria|TDCSR|Chained Oblivion}, made the mountain his seat of power. The {@deity Oblivion's|Exandria|TDCSR|Chained Oblivion} inexorable might corrupted the mountain, stretching its stone-like putty until it was a jagged needle that towered over all other mountains, and etching a mind-bending labyrinth of twisting passages into the mountain's heart.

Acek spread the {@deity Oblivion's|Exandria|TDCSR|Chained Oblivion} nihilistic despair across the {@book Cliffkeep Mountains|TDCSR|4|Cliffkeep Mountains} and the {@book Dividing Plains|TDCSR|4|Dividing Plains} below. All bowed before their influence their minds lost to unfathomable contemplation of the end of all things. Untold thousands died at the hands of Acek and his god, willingly entering {@book Gatshadow|TDCSR|4|Gatshadow}—which then became their tomb.

The bitter cold of oblivion threatened to consume the land, but it was repulsed by the {@deity The Dawnfather|Exandria|TDCSR|Dawnfather} and his warriors of light. The {@deity The Dawnfather|Exandria|TDCSR|Dawnfather} struck a telling blow against the Oblivion, and doggedly pursued as it retreated to {@book Gatshadow|TDCSR|4|Gatshadow}. He shackled and banished the god of the end within {@book Gatshadow's|TDCSR|4|Gatshadow} depths. It was said that Acek's mind and spirit were so saturated with his master's essence that the god's banishment tore his body asunder. Today, only the empty maze of deadly chambers and traps remain beneath the mountain, forgotten and awaiting discovery.

The high bluffs of {@book Gatshadow|TDCSR|4|Gatshadow} have in recent years been the home of many a villain, most recently Umbrasyl the Hope Devourer, the black dragon of the {@book Chroma Conclave|TDCSR|2|The Chroma Conclave}. Legend says that {@book Gatshadow's|TDCSR|4|Gatshadow} interior tunnels spiral infinitely downwards, into a void of utter darkness. Immortal, white-eyed devotees of the {@deity Oblivion|Exandria|TDCSR|Chained Oblivion} pace endlessly into {@book Gatshadow's|TDCSR|4|Gatshadow} tunnels, carrying lightless torches, whispering that the secret to freeing their god from the Divine Gate is sealed in the depths below. The stone doors that bar entrance to {@book Gatshadow's|TDCSR|4|Gatshadow} lowest reaches are sealed by magic so great, even the most inquisitive of the {@book Arcana Pansophical|TDCSR|3|Arcana Pansophical} can't breach them—and it is well that they cannot, for who knows what terror would be unleashed if they were opened.

entries.name: Gatshadow Adventures
entries: Game Masters who set their adventure in {@book Gatshadow|TDCSR|4|Gatshadow} can use these plot hooks for inspiration.

entries.name: Blood of the Dragon (high-level)
entries: The body of the {@creature ancient black dragon} Umbrasyl was never recovered. Some think that's a waste of a perfectly good business opportunity—after all, a black dragon's bones are a potent alchemical reagent, and its scales stronger than any steel.

However, there's a reason no one has dared to recover the Hope Devourer's corpse. When Umbrasyl died, the caustic acid and magical blood within his body seeped through the caverns of Upper {@book Gatshadow|TDCSR|4|Gatshadow}, devouring stone and transforming the mountain's upper levels into a vitriolic maze teeming with oozes, half-black dragon warriors, and the restless spirits of {@book goliaths|TDCSR|5|Half-Giants} from the Herd of Storms that failed to kill the dragon.

entries.name: No Lights in the Darkness (epic-level)
entries: The {@book Betrayer Gods|TDCSR|3|Betrayer Gods} were banished to their planes of eternal imprisonment, but something has upset the laws of the planes. A being called the Nameless—supposedly a cultist of {@deity The Whispered One|Exandria|TDCSR}—has stolen her master's secret knowledge and fled to {@book Gatshadow|TDCSR|4|Gatshadow} in search of the tortured spirit of Acek Orattim. Agents of the {@book Arcana Pansophical|TDCSR|3|Arcana Pansophical} have sensed that the lower gates of {@book Gatshadow|TDCSR|4|Gatshadow} have been breached, and frantically call for Tal'Dorei's greatest heroes to rush to the evil mountain. As the characters hurry to the bottom of the mind-sundering labyrinth within, they discover that they race against not only the new Herald of Oblivion, but also the {@book Remnants|TDCSR|3|The Remnants} she betrayed.

entries.name: Jorenn Village

items.name: Large Village:
entries: Population 2,480 (64% {@book humans|TDCSR|5|humans}, 9% {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves}, 7% {@book halflings|TDCSR|5|halflings}, 7% {@book gnomes|TDCSR|5|gnomes}, 13% {@book other races|TDCSR|5|Other Races})

For many years, Jorenn Village was just a tiny pioneer town trying to profit from the shadegrass of the {@book Umbra Hills|TDCSR|4|Umbra Hills}. Over the past century, the village has exploded in size and population, after plentiful silver veins were discovered within the nearby rocky hills.

Hardworking common folk and opportunistic prospectors alike flocked to Jorenn, despite its unsettling proximity to the {@book Umbra Hills|TDCSR|4|Umbra Hills}. Jorenn is far enough away from {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} that the influence of the {@book Tal'Dorei Council|TDCSR|3|Tal'Dorei Council} rarely touches it, giving opportunists and outlaws freedom to subvert and control both the village government and the local economy. Thirty years ago, a small circle of vigilantes and mercenaries declared themselves protectors of Jorenn, and took the name Shadewatch, hunting and slaying creeping dangers in the night and returning to great fanfare. Over the past three decades, others seeking fame and glory joined the ranks of the Shadewatch, and the group ballooned into the unofficial town law enforcement.

The Shadewatch is deeply corrupt, and it has been almost since its first year. The vigilantes personally stoke the fires of fear, all while demanding increasingly galling tribute for their services—and breaking kneecaps if they don't get it. Today, the people of Jorenn are just as afraid of the Shadewatch as they are of the creatures the watch keeps at bay.

The Shadewatch is a minor organization in the grand scheme of things, but Shademaster Arhanna Lewyn has grand ambitions. She has sent messages to every faction in Tal'Dorei, from the {@book Myriad|TDCSR|3|The Myriad} to the {@book League of Miracles|TDCSR|3|League of Miracles}, with an interest in cruel subterfuge. It's clear that she's planning something: every night, she consults a ball of polished white quartz, and every week she sends a trio of her agents to the {@book Umbra Hills|TDCSR|4|Umbra Hills}—or to the base of {@book Gatshadow|TDCSR|4|Gatshadow}.

entries.name: Jorenn Village Adventures
entries: Game Masters who set their adventure in Jorenn Village can use this plot hook for inspiration.

entries.name: An Offer You Can't Refuse (low-level)
entries: The characters are attacked by a group of {@creature worg|MM|worgs}, and more just keep coming. Just as they're about to be completely overwhelmed, they're saved by a sudden volley of black-feathered bolts! Six thugs join the battle and "rescue" the characters by driving off the remaining {@creature worg|MM|worgs}. These Shadewatch "officers" ask for the characters' names first, then brusquely declare that they like their moxie. They offer the characters a position in their force back in Jorenn, with unbelievable pay: 50 gp a day each.

If this deal sounds too good to be true, that's because it is: the Shademaster needs strong-willed sacrifices if she's to open the gates of {@book Gatshadow|TDCSR|4|Gatshadow}, a feat she can accomplish by teleporting up to twelve creatures into the depths of the mountain with her whispering quartz orb.

entries.name: Kraghammer

items.name: City:
entries: Population 73,550 (73% {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves}, 8% {@book gnomes|TDCSR|5|gnomes}, 5% {@book humans|TDCSR|5|humans}, 14% {@book other races|TDCSR|5|Other Races})

Dozens of dwarven redoubts rose and fell in the tunnels beneath the {@book Cliffkeep Mountains|TDCSR|4|Cliffkeep Mountains} during the {@book Calamity|TDCSR|2|The Calamity}, and in the uncertain years that followed it. Legend holds that a great civilization called Uthtor once reigned supreme in the {@book Cliffkeeps|TDCSR|4|Cliffkeep Mountains}, and that all of the deep settlements are fragments of Uthtor's glory, fractured by the {@book Calamity|TDCSR|2|The Calamity}. Over the centuries, these fragments divided and coalesced dozens of times until, finally, those who remained came together to create Kraghammer.

Clan Jaggenstrike united thousands of {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves}, {@book gnomes|TDCSR|5|gnomes}, and other dwellers of the deep halls in the creation of Kraghammer. Having quietly died out centuries ago, the clan now holds a position of mythic reverence within the city. Kraghammer's founding was dedicated to the {@deity The All-Hammer|Exandria|TDCSR|All-Hammer}, divine creator of the {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} and patron of creation and ingenuity. This god's industrious spirit filled the people of Kraghammer and blessed them with rich veins of {@item platinum|PHB}, mithral, adamantine, and other precious metals that have sustained them since the city's founding.

An ominous walk of a thousand stairs climbs the side of the mountain to the gates of the city—carved from the mountain itself, just wide enough for two {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} to walk abreast. With the path too steep and treacherous for carts or common beasts of burden to traverse, traders and trappers use {@creature giant goat|MM|giant goats} to transport their goods to and from market, while wealthy dwarven merchant lords employ serfs and laborers to carry their goods. Kraghammer's impenetrable adamantine gates stand at the end of a perilous bridge overlooking a hundred-foot chasm, guarded by three watchtowers carved directly into the mountain.

Within those gates, the massive stronghold is made up of three cylindrical levels called "slabs" that descend deep beneath the mountains. Kraghammer's granite walls are lit by roaring fires, enchanted torches, and shimmering candlerock, which glows with internal fire. Even when the evening fires are extinguished, the amber light of the Bronzegrip Metalworks at the base of the city bathes Kraghammer in its warm glow.

entries.name: Government
entries: {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} law is written by a consortium of the five most powerful houses within the city, each appointing a delegate to serve on their behalf. That tenuous union of houses is kept by the city's executive officer, the Ironkeeper. The Ironkeeper is elected by the houses and carries a term of ten years, with no term limit, though most Ironkeepers contain their rule to three to five terms.

The current sitting Ironkeeper is {@book Palluda of House Zuurthom|TDCSR|3|Ironkeeper Palluda Zuurthom}. She rose to prominence advocating for the rights of workers in the wake of the {@book Chroma Conclave|TDCSR|2|The Chroma Conclave}, and is a strong advocate for uniting with the Republic of Tal'Dorei to strengthen their might against future supernatural threats. She is sitting comfortably in the midst of her second term and enjoys strong support from members of {@book Kraghammer's|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} working class—and staunch opposition from traditionalists, who cling to the city's fading culture of {@book isolationism|TDCSR|4|Isolation of Kraghammer}.

The laws of the city are enforced by a military class of elite warriors called Carvers that act as guards, soldiers, and jailers under the guidance of the Ironkeeper. Becoming a Carver is a lengthy, rigorous, and taxing pursuit, and many who choose to join fail to complete their training.

Most who join the Carvers are {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} from families with centuries of history within the Carvers. This isn't just because of the pressure to uphold their family's honor. Most hopefuls are also those who value {@book Kraghammer's|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} ancient traditions and rigid social order—a set of beliefs largely held by dwarven clans with long family histories. Once officially named, a Carver is given a homestead built into the center slab of the city, a set of immaculate armor and weapons, and a steady income.

In the years following the defeat of the {@book Chroma Conclave|TDCSR|2|The Chroma Conclave}, the famously {@book isolationist|TDCSR|4|Isolation of Kraghammer} and xenophobic houses conceded to formally make an alliance with the Republic of Tal'Dorei. An ambassador from {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} now sits on the {@book Tal'Dorei Council|TDCSR|3|Tal'Dorei Council}, and rumors are beginning to circulate within the city that the heads of the Great {@book Houses of Kraghammer|TDCSR|3|Houses of Kraghammer} are in talks with the {@book Tal'Dorei Council|TDCSR|3|Tal'Dorei Council} to make {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} an official constituent city-state of the republic.

entries.title: Art Credit: {@link Andy Law|http://artstation.com/andylaw1}
entries.altText: A cross-sectioned map of Kraghammer showing the underground network of dwarfish tunnels beneath the mountain. On top is The Arch, the middle is The Heart, the bottom is The Pit, with Keenstone Quarry below that. Much further down are the Emberhold and Yug'voril.

entries.name: Isolation of Kraghammer
entries: It's not easy being an outsider. {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} has long been a city of {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves}, for {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves}, and anyone else within the city is an interloper. Some traditionalists within the city still think that surface-born folk should spend as little time in {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} as possible, so as not to dilute the ancient splendor of their culture.

Yet times are changing. A coalition of people, ranging from {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} to {@book gnomes|TDCSR|5|gnomes} to traditionally surface-dwelling people who have made {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} their home, have demanded that the Great Houses amend the city's most xenophobic laws. Despite the angry protestations of the city's most bigoted {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves}, the Great Houses have acquiesced to the requests of their people. This is due in no small part to these protestors having the support of the current Ironkeeper—{@book Palluda Zuurthrom|TDCSR|3|Ironkeeper Palluda Zuurthom} has long been a proponent of {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} entering the Republic of Tal'Dorei and ending their centuries of relative isolation.

No non-dwarf has ever served as a delegate of the houses, let alone the Ironkeeper. Progress is slow, especially in {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer}, but it is happening. The most despicable of the city's xenophobes have left of their own volition, creating other dwarven settlements throughout the {@book Cliffkeeps|TDCSR|4|Cliffkeep Mountains} where they can keep to themselves and "their own kind" in peace.

entries.name: Crime
entries: Citizens of {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} who visit {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} often marvel at how lawful and organized the dwarven enclave is. Crime is ostensibly low within {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} thanks to the Carvers' protection, but this peace comes at a cost. Crime is low because the courts of {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} almost always reach a guilty verdict. As a long-lived and durable people, most {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves}, particularly those with a family reputation to uphold, would rather plead guilty and endure years, even decades, of hard labor than disturb the fabric of their society by fighting conviction.

Beyond this, corruption is rife within the Carvers, and they are able to brutalize even innocent people with relative impunity. This corruption is shielded from public scrutiny by the vast wealth and political influence of House Glorendar, their patron house. Because of Glorendar's close ties with the Carvers (and the mutual benefits thereof), corruption has been hard to uncover within either organization.

Over twenty years ago, however, a gnomish journalist named Ida Mudrake uncovered something damning within the vaults of House Glorendar, bringing some hope that change may yet move steadily forward. She has been forced to flee the city and now lives with a security detail in {@book Emon|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship}, but she works tirelessly to bring the crimes of House Glorendar to light. Many in {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} hope that this evidence, whatever it is, will shake both Glorendar and the Carvers to their foundations. Many more fear that even true justice is not worth the chaos that bringing Glorendar's misdeeds to light will cause.

entries.name: Geography and Climate
entries: Though the {@book Cliffkeep Mountains|TDCSR|4|Cliffkeep Mountains} themselves are blanketed in thick snow, the bone-piercing chill does not extend into {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} itself. Heat from the Bronzegrip Metalworks and the other blast furnaces in the Bottom Slab rises and permeates the entire city, though the Top Slab still grows cold in the winter. The city itself is carved out of the granite core of Mount {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer}; though the {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} rarely see the night sky, the inner walls still sparkle like starlight in the amber glow of the furnaces.

entries.name: Top Slab
entries: Also called the Arch, this uppermost tier is the entry level of the city, built on a massive ring. Like a hub with many spokes, countless neighborhoods and tunnels spread out from the Top Slab. A fine layer of soot tends to coat much of this slab, due to imperfect ventilation from the industrious center slab; despite this, this level is where most people make their homes, with thousands of stone-built abodes dotting the walls, while popular taverns like the trendy Firebrook Inn and the historic but austere Ironhearth Tavern fill alcoves pushed into the rock. For hundreds of years, most non-dwarves within {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} were relegated to living in a Top Slab neighborhood called the "Otherwalk." These days, non-dwarves live all over the city, and the Otherwalk has been renamed the Cavernwalk. It's still mostly inhabited by non-dwarves, and it has a vibrant culture all its own.

As members of the {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} working class, "Topslabbers" either make the long commute to labor in the Bottom Slab or work in the Toppers' farms above the mountain. Others are indentured servants to wealthy {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} in the Middle Slab, and only return to their families on the Top Slab on their monthly day of rest.

entries.name: Center Slab
entries: Also referred to as the Heart, this middle tier is the widest and most varied rung on the journey through {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer}. It is stratified between the residences of {@book Kraghammer's|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} old money (its long-established noble houses), and the new (the wealthy merchant class). At the exact center of the slab is the Pyrethrone, seat of the Ironkeeper. The geometric symbolism of the Pyrethrone being at the dead center of the city is a fact most visitors to {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} hear ad nauseum. Radiating out from the Pyrethrone are the various fortress-manors of the dwarven noble houses, with several Carver barracks in easy reach.

Below, the outer rings of the Center Slab are occupied by most of the city's non-mining businesses, from smithies, breweries, and jewelers, to tailors, butchers, and tinkerers like the {@book Cracksackle Union|TDCSR|4|Cracksackle Guildhall (Middle Slab)}. The Hunter's Club is also well known as the chief provider for non-imported meats to the city, sending parties into the mountains or the nearby {@book Torian Forest|TDCSR|4|Torian Forest} for wild game. The extravagant marble temple known as {@deity The All-Hammer|Exandria|TDCSR|All-Hammer's Will} stands on the center slab of the city, the grandest of all shrines to the most worshipped deity under the mountain. Enormous in size and impeccable in both detail and architectural design, this hall calls to artisans and crafters throughout the city for inspiration.

Of the five noble houses, only two conduct their affairs entirely in the Center Slab. The magically talented Lord Steddos Thunderbrand and his family are known to rarely leave their mansion, except on business with the Ironkeeper. Wallera Glorendar used to oversee the combat training of all Carvers within {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer}, but hasn't been seen in public for twenty years. Her daughter, Kazya, runs all her affairs within the public eye.

entries.name: Bottom Slab
entries: Best known as the Pit, this tier is the industrious powerhouse of {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer}, boasting the most forges per square mile of any location in Tal'Dorei, courtesy of the Bronzegrip Metalworks and their competitors. Most of these forges are potent, highly industrialized, and mechanized blast furnaces. The expansive {@book Keenstone Quarry|TDCSR|4|Keenstone Quarry (Bottom Slab)} is chief among the numerous mining operations that have tunneled through the depths of the mountains—depths whose true dangers are obscured by centuries of legend, and therefore not fully understood.

A network of fungus-farming paths called the Glowgrove works its way around this level, passing through all sorts of caverns. The mushrooms are harvested by the Toppers, the dwarven agricultural league that got their name from the small topside farms they tend above the city.

Three of the five dwarven houses have business interests in the Bottom Slab, though they direct its operations from the next tier up. {@book Nostoc Greyspine|TDCSR|3|Lord Nostoc Greyspine} is the grim overseer of {@book Keenstone Quarry|TDCSR|4|Keenstone Quarry (Bottom Slab)}. Haddi Bronzegrip is the foredwarf of the Bronzegrip Metalworks; she claims to be the wealthiest dwarf in the North, a claim no one has ever been able to successfully dispute. Blenton Zuurthom is an architectural savant, and one of the older and kinder noble {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves}; he tries his best to oversee every major construction project in the Bottom Slab.

entries.title: Art Credit: {@link Brian Syme|http://artstation.com/bryansyme}
entries.altText: Two individuals hammer on an anvil at the base of a large, black forge which looms over them. The glow of flames emanate from four faces carved into the designs of the forge and several vents.

entries.name: Points of Interest
entries: {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} has a number of famous landmarks, as well as a few mythic locations said to exist in the caverns beneath the city, as depicted on its map.

entries.name: The Starshrine (Top Slab)
entries: Most {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} worship the {@deity The All-Hammer|Exandria|TDCSR|All-Hammer}, and his teachings of community and ancestral piety have been all but completely subsumed into {@book Kraghammer's|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} culture at large. For outlanders with different faiths, however, the monolithic religious culture can feel inescapable. Shrines to all the {@book Prime Deities|TDCSR|3|Prime Deities} have spread throughout {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} since the fall of the {@book Chroma Conclave|TDCSR|2|The Chroma Conclave}, but the Starshrine was the first.

When the world trembled at the might of {@book Thordak the Cinder King|TDCSR|2|Thordak, the Cinder King}, tremors rocked the upper layers of {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer}, causing certain caverns to collapse—and in some cases, to reveal places of great beauty. The Starshrine is a vast grotto whose granite walls mysteriously sparkle with a perfect replica of the stars in the night sky. It can be found within the Top Slab's culturally diverse Cavernwalk district. Once per year, when a character prays to one of the {@book Prime Deities|TDCSR|3|Prime Deities} here, there is a {@chance 1||Starshrine Prayer|Your prayer is answered!|Your prayer goes unanswered.} chance per character level that their prayer is answered, as the cleric's {@classFeature Divine Intervention|Cleric|PHB|10|PHB} class feature.

entries.name: Cracksackle Guildhall (Middle Slab)
entries: The headquarters of the Cracksackle Union looks unlike anything in {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer}. It's made of a dozen glistening steel domes, like sleek, metal igloos, and the light of unusual experiments flicker through its slitted windows at all hours of the night. Most within {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} consider the building an eyesore, but all interested in technological tinkering and ingenuity love it for its uniqueness. If nothing else, it plainly displays the oft-baffling ingenuity of its tinkerers.

The Cracksackle Union was founded by gnomish refugees from {@book Wittebak|TDCSR|4|Pools of Wittebak} nearly four hundred years ago. While intrinsically tied to the Bronzegrip Metalworks for resources, contacts, and distribution, the Cracksacklers have made themselves indispensable to the dwarven elite with their inventive contributions to mining and masonry technology.

On any working day, a dozen tinkerers, many of them {@book gnomes|TDCSR|5|gnomes}, will set up shop in the courtyard, selling strange and untested devices they have made in their workshops. The GM determines which non-magical curiosities can be purchased here, but some include:

entries.name: Keenstone Quarry (Bottom Slab)
entries: Despite all of {@book Kraghammer's|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} wondrous crafts and goods, its most significant export is raw stone—most of which is excavated from Keenstone Quarry, making the quarry's overseer, {@book Nostoc Greyspine|TDCSR|3|Lord Nostoc Greyspine}, a very rich dwarf indeed. As the legend of Vox Machina spread across Tal'Dorei, {@book Overseer Greyspine|TDCSR|3|Lord Nostoc Greyspine} got an idea: open the quarry to adventurers. Vox Machina famously entered the vast network of dangerous tunnels beneath {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} from a fissure at the depths of the quarry, and countless imitators have tried to follow in their footsteps—some emerging with fabulous treasure, but most never returning at all.

To take advantage of this opportunity, {@book Greyspine|TDCSR|3|Lord Nostoc Greyspine} has advertised the quarry far and wide as the "Gateway to the Depths," and posted an entrance fee of 25 gp per adventurer. Of course, neither {@book Greyspine|TDCSR|3|Lord Nostoc Greyspine} nor the staff of the quarry bears any liability for death, dismemberment, or emotional trauma sustained with the depths.

entries.name: Hall of Burning Mushrooms
entries: The Bronzegrip Metalworks just carved deeper into the mountain to expand their furnaces, only to discover the most magnificent cavern: a mile-wide cave filled with bioluminescent purple mushrooms. Industry had to move in, and the Bronzegrips hired Wyrmhide Thunderbrand and his pyromancer brigade to torch the cavern. The mushrooms never stopped burning, and the {@creature myconoid adult|MM|myconids} that lived in the fungal forest never stopped fighting. Characters known within {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} may be requested by House Bronzegrip or Thunderbrand to cut through the inferno and destroy the {@creature myconoid Sovereign|MM|myconid monarch}.

entries.name: Emberhold

items.name: City:
entries: Population 21,180 (73% {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves}, 15% {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves}, 12% {@book other races|TDCSR|5|Other Races})

A passage from the {@book Keenstone Quarry|TDCSR|4|Keenstone Quarry (Bottom Slab)} in {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} leads below the earth. Deep. Deeper. Until the light of day is entirely gone, and then deeper still. Across chasms miles-deep and full of magma, beneath great hanging gardens of glowing {@item malachite}, lies the {@book Emberhold|TDCSR|4|Emberhold}. It stares imperiously over an underground kingdom of the {@creature duergar}, {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} who long ago broke away from the rule of the Great {@book Houses of Kraghammer|TDCSR|3|Houses of Kraghammer}.

Millennia of fear and superstition have turned the {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} of {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} into bitter, fearful enemies of their estranged kin. Untold dozens of duergar villages span the glassy lava-plains that the {@book Emberhold|TDCSR|4|Emberhold} is built upon, with mighty armies constantly coming and going, sometimes returning with just a few bloody survivors, other times returning with captives in chains—and other times returning not at all.

The {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} of the {@book Emberhold|TDCSR|4|Emberhold} rarely rise to the surface; they have lived so long in the darkest depths of the earth that the light of the sun sears their eyes and prickles their skin. Few ever arise even to {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer}, for they are taught that only death awaits them there. Nevertheless, many duergar doubt the narrative that has been fed to them since birth, and make attempts to escape to the surface. Those duergar that have left the ways of the {@book Emberhold|TDCSR|4|Emberhold} behind and learned of the outside world have remarked how unbelievable it is that their people were so misled by lies about the barbaric cruelty of surface-dwellers.

entries.name: Government
entries: The {@book Emberhold|TDCSR|4|Emberhold} and the towns that serve as its vassals are ruled by an absolute monarch. The current King of Embers is the wrathful King Thangrul II. He rules through fear and conquest, spreading his armies to the farthest corners of Tal'Dorei's underground caverns in the name of the {@deity The Crawling King|Exandria|TDCSR|Crawling King}.

Thangrul's rule is supported by a contingent of {@creature drow|MM|dark elves} from their decadent, alien domain of {@book Ruhn-Shak|TDCSR|4|Ruhn-Shak}. Most in Thangrul's court know well enough to mistrust these ambassadors of the far-flung caverns, for their minds have been twisted by the influence of not just the {@deity The Spider Queen|Exandria|TDCSR|Spider Queen}, but also the aberrations with whom they have made strange alliances in order to sustain their power. Thangrul himself cares little for his advisors' mistrust of his elven allies and openly declares that he will make use of them as long as they are useful.

Vox Machina's assault of the {@book Emberhold|TDCSR|4|Emberhold} over twenty years ago cost the duergar their king and queen, but rumors of a lost princess of Ember have begun to circulate through the realm, and the survivors of Vox Machina's raid have rebuilt their hierarchy and continued their endless war of conquest throughout the depths.

entries.name: Geography
entries: The {@book Emberhold|TDCSR|4|Emberhold} itself is a fortress built of black stone and {@item obsidian}, framed by rivers of molten rock and surrounded by a massive city of ramshackle dwellings and towers that mark the boundaries of its peoples' domain.

entries.name: Emberhold Adventures
entries: Game Masters who set their adventure in the {@book Emberhold|TDCSR|4|Emberhold} can use this plot hook for inspiration.

entries.name: The Lost Heir (mid-level)
entries: King Murghol of the {@book Emberhold|TDCSR|4|Emberhold} was killed in combat by {@creature Scanlan Shorthalt|TDCSR}, gnome bard of Vox Machina, and his wife, Queen Ulara, was slain by the aberrant tyrant K'Varn. All of the {@book Emberhold|TDCSR|4|Emberhold} knows that the King and Queen had a young daughter—only six years old at the time of their death—but none seem interested in seeking {@book Emberhold's|TDCSR|4|Emberhold} missing heir. The new king, Thangrul II, grows particularly fiery whenever anyone mentions her name in his presence.

entries.name: Yug'Voril
entries: Where the {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} of {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} whisper fearful words of the {@creature duergar}, so too do the {@creature duergar} whisper of Yug'Voril. Beneath the deep {@book dwarves'|TDCSR|5|dwarves} fiery kingdom, ever deeper into the heart of Exandria, there is a miles-wide grotto coated in glowing crystal. A lake fills the grotto, its surface so smooth and placid it seems like a {@item jade} mirror, perfectly reflecting the light of the crystals around it. In the middle of the lake is an island, atop which loom the grand, austere towers of Yug'Voril.
The clean lines and beautiful facade of the city belie its current, abominable denizens.

Thousands of years old, the builders and previous occupants have long vanished, leaving the unspoiled ruins to become home to a host of {@creature mind flayer|MM|psychic, mind-eating creatures} from a plane beyond the boundaries of reality. The tyrannical society of these alien creatures flourishes here, far from their cosmic pursuers, giving them the freedom to build a legion of thralls: mind-slaves whose delicious brains are allowed to remain in their bodies...until those bodies fall apart from toil.

Yug'Voril and {@creature mind flayer|MM|its inhabitants} fell recently under the control of the extraplanar aberration called K'Varn, before he was slain by Vox Machina. Now that the {@creature mind flayer|MM|alien mind-eaters} have been freed from K'Varn's tyranny, they have reclaimed Yug'Voril as their own and have continued work on their strange and terrible plots.

entries.name: Yug'Voril Adventures
entries: Game Masters who set their adventure in {@book Yug'Voril|TDCSR|4|Yug'Voril} can use this plot hook for inspiration.

entries.name: A Mind Is a Terrible Thing to Waste (high-level)
entries: Four of the foremost minds at {@book Emon's|TDCSR|4|Emon, the City of Fellowship} {@book Alabaster Lyceum|TDCSR|4|5. Alabaster Lyceum} have disappeared without a trace. All vanished on the same night, and there have been no confirmed sightings since. Investigations have been underway for several months, and some {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves} of {@book Kraghammer|TDCSR|4|Kraghammer} have recently reported seeing four figures that could be the missing scholars entering the lower passages of the {@book Keenstone Mine|TDCSR|4|Keenstone Quarry (Bottom Slab)} under cover of night.
Something has mentally dominated these scholars. The alien inhabitants of {@book Yug'Voril|TDCSR|4|Yug'Voril} hunger for a specific morsel of powerful knowledge within their brilliant minds.

entries.name: Lyrengorn, the Elvenpeaks

items.name: Town:
entries: Population 5,430 (93% {@book elves|TDCSR|5|elves}, 3% {@book dwarves|TDCSR|5|dwarves}, 2% {@book humans|TDCSR|5|humans}, 2% {@book other races|TDCSR|5|Other Races})

Every year, dozens of travelers from across Tal'Dorei travel past the far northern reaches of the {@book Cliffkeep Mountains|TDCSR|4|Cliffkeep Mountains} to see the {@deity The Moonweaver|Exandria|TDCSR|Moonweaver's} Ribbons twist around the Elvenpeaks, pulled through the sky by those mysterious figures on {@creature wyvern|MM|wyvernback}. The Elvenpeaks are a single mountain split perfectly in the center, with ice-sheeted forests topping both peaks. While the exterior of these forest canopies appears frozen and without life, the interior is instead a warm and humid wood, blooming with flowers of all colors and roamed by living plants and wild game.
